You hold your finger down on the remote and the channels start flipping faster and faster, at the speed of a hummingbird’s wings. The channels are endless. They contain the media of every civilization that has ever existed. Within a minute you flip through 100 million channels. Getting the idea, you lift your finger from the remote. It stops on what looks like an HD nature documentary. You see a slow-motion macro shot of a hummingbird flapping its wings. The camera zooms out and you see yourself standing next to it in the desert, admiring its beauty.
This is only making me question why I hallucinate without psychedelics. It would be interesting to see my already hallucinating brain on psychedelics.

Actually, technically these are called pseudohallucinations and not hallucinations. But I can understand using the term "hallucination" as a sort of umbrella term for any spurious sensory perception for the sake of convenience.

The definition given on Wiki is: "a perception in the absence of external stimulus that has qualities of real perceptions." Which include visions of people, objects, places etc which are indistinguishable from reality. For example, a person suffering from delirium may see a friend of theirs' walk into the room and have a conversation with them for several minutes, only then to have the person dissolve into nothingness and suddenly realize that the whole thing was just a hallucination. Or a common one among smokers is smoking cigarettes which aren't even there.

Anticholinergic drugs or plants like atropine, scopolamine, over the counter medications for nausea and motion sickness and benedryl, which contain the drug diphenhydramine, although motion sickness medications list the active ingredient as "dimenhydrinate" this is just a combination of diphenhydramine and another drug called 8-chlorotheophylline which has a slight stimulant effect to mitigate the drowsiness it causes, but I digress. Other things that could cause delirium include plants like atropa belladonna, datura, and green potatoes.

These will cause a state of anticholinergic toxicity when taken in abundance, which will lead to exactly these sorts of hallucinations. But don't let any would-be psychonauts be tantalized by the notion of tripping or getting high on these plant/drugs. As I said, the "high" is really a form of toxicity and reports indicate it feels more like a fever dream than anything enjoyable. The can also cause side effects like cardiac arrhythmias, strokes, heart attacks, seizures, inability to urinate while also producing an excessive amount of urine. Whichwould be my idea of a living nightmare and severe short term memory loss. To the point where people on it will forget what they're Between the realism of the hallucinations and the severe short term memory loss it causes, often the user won't even realize they've taken anything. So they're not even aware that there's anything unusual about their state of mind.

In short, according to the technical definition, the effects being described in this video are pseudohallucinations, while actual hallucinations are indistinguishable from real sensory input.

wow i am so impressed by this video, specifically by exactly how much you understand and explain something i've personally experienced and became interested in researching at an amateur level that i have struggled to explain or didn't dig deep enough to find research on it (if it even existed during the time i was doing that)

i have taken a lot of psychedelics in my life but i never used them at all until i was 25. around then i started using THC, then LSD, then shrooms, etc. psychology, mental health and neurology are some of my special interests and i had many reasons for this...journey, as i like to think of it (i only use THC now, LSD very rarely) but i had already asked myself many of the same questions you addressed the answers to succinctly in this video. i knew that meditating sober could bring about psychedelic experiences (it's happened to me sober...also meditating on LSD is a thing too) due to it suppressing the DNN, but i didn't actually know WHY it suppresses the DNN until now.

i am also extremely interested in color theory and had already read several extremely touching accounts of colorblind people seeing colors for the first time on LSD. i remember reading one trip report where the colorblind guy took LSD while his sober friend looked after him to keep him safe while tripping. he started seeing colors and became so excited that his friend spent the entire trip introducing him to new colors and teaching him all the names for them.

since my own color perception goes back to normal after LSD wears off, unfortunately i have to assume this guy went back to being colorblind, but that's not a certain assumption since LSD also has an effect on things such as heightening neuroplasticity and who knows, maybe my color perception actually was worse before i started taking psychedelics. (speculation)

the other part of your video was the point where you said that adult brains on LSD are similar to that of children: again i experience NOTICING this myself with personal use but having no proper explanation for it at the time.

the first time i got really really stoned, my first thought was "Wow...time hasn't been this slow since I was about 9" (they 100% affect my perception of time and there is research to show that perception of time changes with age/brain development)

but i also started noticing other things from my hallucinations on psychedelics: and i realized MANY of these types of hallucinations where things i could see while sober as a kid, but no longer can see at all when sober as an adult. so my immediate thought upon that realization was "wow, I bet being a child is actually a LOT like being on psychedelics all the time..."

turns out i was right?? amazing.

My one criticism of this video (as someone with degrees in both neuroscience and chemistry) is the use of the word "efficient". your default mode network (DMN) doesn't have so much to do with efficiency as it does with the brain's standard mode of operation.  In very simplified terms, psychedelics perform a "soft reset" on your brain causing neuronal signals to take paths that aren't typically utilized (paths that weren't strenghtened during the typical person's neuronal development). This is what makes these drugs such promising therapeutic substances for mood disorders like depression, anxiety, PTSD, etc.

You kinda missed pattern recognition as a factor in hallucinations, that’s a core component. It is related to the suppression of the default mode network but it’s separate ish from the effect of ego dissolution. You did sort of imply that there’s a separate effect the DMN suppression with the graph but kind of muddled it when you said that the brain had more information and therefore had to fill in the gaps. It was true but linguistically muddled, what you actually were saying was that the brain can’t deal with all that info and starts making assumptions in order to compensate (a word you did use). But what it probably sounded like to average watchers was contradictory.

Pattern recognition is the result of the influx of information that was previously ignored. This “information” actually just means neurons firing into patterns that have already been set. So with a pool of new info, the “correct” stuff is washed out and circuits fire when they should be still, and this can cause pattern recognition as it can occur in the visual processing region. Circuits that fire when you recognize a pattern go off, this causes hallucinogenic effects that really contribute to the visual aspect of hallucinations under psychedelics that you kind of brushed over

As a Harvard Neuroscientist, any psychoactive drug - whether it be alcohol, marijuana, caffeine, opiates, hallucinogens, or prescriptions - can only exert its actions by hijacking an endogenous system already in place in your brain. For example, your brain and body have an extensive endogenous cannabinoid system which - in the absence of THC from marijuana - serves natural roles in modulating seemingly every function of your nervous system. This is because the overwhelming majority of neurons in your brain produce and use natural cannabinoid ligands to influence the electrical communication between neurons at synapses. Technically speaking, endogenous cannabinoids provide neural activity-dependent, retrograde, metabotropic inhibition to presynaptic inputs of a given neuron. Without all the jargon, this means that when one neuron excites another neuron with a barrage of electrical impulses, the recipient neuron tells the talkative neuron to quiet down a bit - and not overstimulate it - via the use of endogenous cannabinoid signaling as a feedback. When you smoke, inhale, or ingest THC from marijuana, the THC provides a potent external source for binding to endogenous cannabinoid receptors and overrides/hijacks whatever the natural cannabinoid ligands in your brain were doing previously. This results in many THC-induced changes, which can be therapeutic or harmful depending on the concentration and frequency of usage. This example of THC acting on your endogenous cannabinoid system is analogous to what any other psychoactive drug is doing to its targeted natural system in your brain. Nicotine hijacks your brain's natural acetylcholine receptors, while opiates do the same for opiate receptors. Caffeine & alcohol are more complicated simply because they are "dirty" drugs in terms of having a broad binding affinity across many receptor targets, but caffeine has a particularly prominent binding & influence on adenosine receptors to affect wakefulness, for example. While some of these psychoactive drugs can be beneficial if used judiciously, consider that hijacking of your natural systems with regular use may have long-term deleterious effects on your brain & body. Fun Fact: You don't get real Hallucinations from LSD, you only get optics. What's the difference you ask? Well, optics only show what is already there but in a different way, hallucinations cause you to see things that aren't there. For example, when you see something like a shadow that looks like a face, when you hallucinate you may also see a body (which isn't there) and optics make you see the face a bit more clear or with more depth.
Of course, that's just the optical part of LSD, the mental part is a different story and it's not made for everyone. However some people can easily take multiple times the dose than what would be too much for most and wouldn't even be close to a bad trip.
It's the basic mindset which makes the difference. For example, if you are drunk you may or may not be able to realize your level of being drunk and control your actions. It's basically the same principle. You have to be able to metaphorically step outside of yourself and perfrom a full neutral outside view self test and analyses, no matter how high or how drunk you are.

I have yet to find out what causes these differences, but my studying shall continue.
